title: Add a warning when multiple contending scripts are detected
body: * Fixes #34147

title: Actually download metadata in parallel
body: When using the gradle/gradle build as an example, we were never downloading metadata in parallel during graph resolution. This is due to a number of things 1. Our UNCONSTRAINED executer was not actually unconstrained. Its worker threads still required a worker lease, and therefore any work scheduled on an unconstrained executor would still have its concurrency limited to the number of cores on the machine. We fix this by not requiring unconstrained workers to acquire worker leases. 2. When using filtered repositories, we aways returned MetadataFetchingCost.FAST if a dependency did not match our filter. If one repository claims a fast fetching cost, then we short circuit and assume we do not need to download in parallel. Presumably, we had one of the first repos in our build have a filter that did not match many dependencies, so for all metadata fetching we would not download in parallel. So, this commit properly unconstrains the UNCONSTRAINED executer, and fixes filtered repositories so they download metadata in parallel. One thing to note is that we moved artifact resolution to the MAX_WORKERS executor instead of the UNCONSTRAINED executor, since we perform transforms while doing artifact resolution. This means if UNCONSTRAINED actually worked the way it should have worked, we would have been performing way more transforms in parallel than we intended. In practice, since the unconstrained pool was already limited to the number of CPUs, this should make no difference. However, this shows that we are not downloading artifacts with high parallelism. We should somehow update parallel artifact resolution to schedule transforms on the MAX_WORKERS executor and file downloads on the UNCONSTRAINED executor. Before: After: This can reduce the time of dependency resolution by up to half in the gradle/gradle build when running with a fresh GUH ### Reviewing cheatsheet Before merging the PR, comments starting with - ‚ùå ‚ùì**must** be fixed - ü§î üíÖ **should** be fixed - üí≠ **may** be fixed - üéâ celebrate happy things

:internal-integ-testing now depends on the new :internal-distribution-testing

title: Avoid using default PMD ruleset if custom is provided
body:
Fixes #32980 

### Context
This solution is not good, maybe you can point me in the correct solution.

If the user would explicitly configure `ruleSets = ["category/java/errorprone.xml"]`, then this would be ignored as the property has the default value. We would need to figure out, if the user provided just a custom ruleset or also additionally the property ruleSets...

This seems to be working with conventions. Is this possible for the tasks as well?

What's missing: Unit tests (where?), maybe a better documentation to address #8514.

title: Deprecate ResolvedDependency parent artifact methods
body:
ResolvedDependency exposes method that allow dependencies from a certain parent node to be individually requested. Some edges from a given parent may have different dependencies if it has different attributes, excludes, target configurations, or capabilities.

ArtifactView operates on a node-by-node basis and does not operate on edges. We are planning to implement improvements to ArtifactView that will replace ResolvedConfiguration, LenientConfiguration, and ResolvedDependency, but that improvement will remain node-aware and not edge aware.

This commit prepares us for this by deprecating APIs that require data that will not be tracked in future versions of Gradle.

### Reviewing cheatsheet

Before merging the PR, comments starting with 
- ‚ùå ‚ùì**must** be fixed
- ü§î üíÖ **should** be fixed
- üí≠ **may** be fixed
- üéâ celebrate happy things

title: Project root components are identified by root component identifier
body:
Follow-up to https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/33654

Update project root components to live within a synthetic root component identified by a `RootComponentIdentifier`, instead of the project's local component where the variants live. 

This allows resolutions in a project to resolve other version of the project (from external repositories) instead of always being forced to resolve the local version of the project.

Architecturally, this is also a huge win, as we will no longer need two versions of the same local project component state. Previously we created one version to hold the root variants of resolution, and the other to hold the consumable variants.

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/1629

### Reviewing cheatsheet

Before merging the PR, comments starting with 
- ‚ùå ‚ùì**must** be fixed
- ü§î üíÖ **should** be fixed
- üí≠ **may** be fixed
- üéâ celebrate happy things

title: [WIP] Use file locking for immutable workspace for Unix
verify M2 and Ivy patterns contain the required tokens in any pattern
body:
Permit more flexible repository layout patterns.

Instead of strictly checking for an exact repository pattern, instead verify the patterns contain the required tokens.

- M2 patterns must contain: `organisation`, `module`, `artifact`.
- Ivy patterns must contain: `artifact`.

The existing checks already required these tokens. They are still required, but the position is not fixed.

Signed-off-by: Adam <897017+aSemy@users.noreply.github.com>

I've tested this against the example project in #33674 and it works.

Fix #33674

title: Expose public API for async exec in ExecOperations
body:
Support async execution of external processes using ExecOperations.

`ExecOperations#execAsync` returns a `ExecHandle` that can be used to abort, or await the result of, the process.

I created this PR as a demonstration. While Gradle's internal ExecHandle is tested, the new public ExecHandle introduced in this PR should be tested too.

To keep this PR simpler, I didn't introduce the functionality of adding a listener to handle the output logs.

Fix #32502

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
<!-- Fixes #? -->

### Context
<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
<!--- Link to relevant issues or forum discussions here -->

### Contributor Checklist
- [ ] [Review Contribution Guidelines](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
- [ ] Make sure that all commits are [signed off](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-commit#Documentation/git-commit.txt---signoff) to indicate that you agree to the terms of [Developer Certificate of Origin](https://developercertificate.org/).
- [ ] Make sure all contributed code can be distributed under the terms of the [Apache License 2.0](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/master/LICENSE), e.g. the code was written by yourself or the original code is licensed under [a license compatible to Apache License 2.0](https://apache.org/legal/resolved.html).
- [ ] Check ["Allow edit from maintainers" option](https://help.github.com/articles/allowing-changes-to-a-pull-request-branch-created-from-a-fork/) in pull request so that additional changes can be pushed by Gradle team.
- [ ] Provide integration tests (under `<subproject>/src/integTest`) to verify changes from a user perspective.
- [ ] Provide unit tests (under `<subproject>/src/test`) to verify logic.
- [ ] Update User Guide, DSL Reference, and Javadoc for public-facing changes.
- [ ] Ensure that tests pass sanity check: `./gradlew sanityCheck`.
- [ ] Ensure that tests pass locally: `./gradlew <changed-subproject>:quickTest`.

### Reviewing cheatsheet

Before merging the PR, comments starting with 
- ‚ùå ‚ùì**must** be fixed
- ü§î üíÖ **should** be fixed
- üí≠ **may** be fixed
- üéâ celebrate happy things

labels.name: :wave: team-triage
labels.description: Issues that need to be triaged by a specific team

title: [WIP] Implement Multi lock cache
Prepare compiler workers for splitting into separate projects
body:
Use only fully immutable classes for the specs we send to the java, scala, and groovy compiler workers. Also ensure they are constructed in a way that they do not have compile-time dependenices on the mutable DSL types that they are generated from.
